messages.content: Write a cover letter for a job at a local coffee shop in the form of a poem. Highlight at least 5 text sections using "*". For example: *3 years of experience*.

Dear Steam-Rose Café,  
I come on the wings of *espresso-scented dawn*,  
a mug in one hand, a résumé in the other,  
and a heart that beats in 4/4 *latte-art rhythm*.  

I have *3 years of experience* coaxing crema  
from reluctant beans, teaching milk to swirl  
into hearts, tulips, and once—*a near-perfect phoenix*.  
I know the hush before the morning rush,  
the *symphony of clinking ceramic*,  
the soft *hiss of steam* that says, “Good morning,  
you are not alone.”  

I can *calibrate a grinder* by ear,  
dial in sweetness like a poet finds metaphor,  
and still remember the name of the woman  
who orders *oat-milk cappuccino, half-pump vanilla*.  
I have *wiped counters into mirrors*,  
swept floors into runways for tiny dogs  
and toddlers in rain boots.  

I believe a tip jar can be a wishing well,  
that decaf drinkers deserve *symphony*, not apology,  
and that every *first sip* is a small resurrection.  
If you need someone who can *thrive at 5:59 a.m.*,  
who greets silence and chaos with the same grin,  
who counts *seconds of extraction* like rosary beads—  
then I am already pulling on my apron,  
warming cups with the *palm of promise*.  

May I steam for you?

messages.content: Write a casual blog post about similarities across animal species. Highlight at least 5 sections in your answer by starting and ending with "*", like: *highlighted text section*.

*We’re all just cousins with fur, feathers, or scales*  
I spent last weekend binge-watching nature documentaries in my pajamas, and the same thought kept popping up: the animal kingdom is basically one big extended family reunion where everyone forgot to send out the dress-code memo. From the tiniest ant to the splashiest whale, we keep running into the same life hacks over and over again. Here are five of my favorite “wait, we do that too!” moments.

*Play isn’t just for puppies*  
Turns out, *everyone needs recess*. Scientists have filmed ravens sliding down snowy roofs on their backs, dolphins surfing waves for fun, and even octopuses (octopi? octopodes?) juggling empty shells like bored kids with fidget spinners. The common thread? Big brains and long childhoods. If you’ve got time to learn, you’ve got time to goof off.

*Grandma knows best*  
Elephant herds led by wizened old matriarchs survive droughts way better than younger crews. Orca grandmothers babysit while mom hunts. And—plot twist—*human grandmas might be the reason we live past menopause*. The “grandmother hypothesis” says that by sticking around to help feed and teach grandkids, elder females turbo-charged our species’ smarts. Gray hair is basically a superhero cape.

*Love stinks (in a good way)*  
Whether you’re a mouse, a meerkat, or a middle-schooler, *smell is the original dating app*. Mice sniff out immune-system differences to avoid kissing cousins. Humans subconsciously rate sweaty T-shirts for genetic compatibility. Even plants get in on the game—orchids fake the scent of female bees to lure in pollen-carrying males. Swipe right on pheromones.

*Teamwork makes the dream work*  
Army ants build living bridges out of their own bodies. Penguins huddle in rotating circles so everyone gets a turn in the warm center. And *those viral videos of capybaras chilling with crocodiles?* That’s mutualism—one species gets dental hygiene (yes, the crocs let little birds pick their teeth), the other gets lunch. Nature’s Airbnb: leave a five-star review and nobody gets eaten.

*Everybody poops, and that’s a feature, not a bug*  
Dung beetles navigate by the Milky Way (seriously, they’re tiny astronomers). Hippos use poop to mark territory. Parrotfish poop out sand—hello, tropical beaches. *One creature’s waste is another’s waterfront property*. The takeaway? Nothing in nature is trash; it’s just someone else’s treasure waiting to happen.

So next time you feel like an awkward outsider at the planetary party, remember: we’re all just variations on a theme. Some of us just happen to have better tail designs.

messages.content:
Generate a business proposal to start a sweatshirt company in Bremen. The proposal should contain 5 or more sections. Highlight each section name using the this format:
*section name*

*Executive Summary*
Bremen is a city where maritime heritage meets cutting-edge creativity, yet it lacks a locally-rooted premium sweatshirt brand that speaks to both its seafaring soul and its thriving student, start-up, and creative scenes. “Bremer Fleece” will fill that gap by producing small-batch, design-forward sweatshirts that celebrate Bremen’s Hanseatic symbols, street-art culture, and eco-conscious values. Our mission is to become the go-to layer for every Bremen resident who wants warmth, style, and a story. We will launch with an initial investment of €75 k, reach break-even within 18 months, and scale to €350 k annual revenue by year three.

*Market Analysis*
Bremen & Bremerhaven host 550 k residents, 35 k university students, and 1.2 million annual tourists. Surveys (n = 312) show 68 % of 18-35-year-olds buy at least one sweatshirt per year, yet only 12 % can name a local brand. Competitor mapping reveals three gaps: (1) no Bremen-specific iconography, (2) limited sustainable options, and (3) no on-demand customization. Tourists spend €45–€70 on souvenirs; locals spend €60–€90 on quality streetwear. By positioning at €69–€89 retail, we target both segments without direct price overlap with global fast-fashion or luxury labels.

*Product & Sustainability Strategy*
All sweatshirts will be 85 % GOTS-certified organic cotton / 15 % recycled PET fleece, manufactured in Portugal under Fair-Wear audits. Core graphics—designed in collaboration with local illustrators—feature the Bremer Stadtmusikanten silhouette re-imagined in street-art style, the Weser river wave, and subtle maritime signal-flag typography. Each drop is limited to 300 pieces, serialized with NFC tags that unlock AR experiences (e.g., a 3-minute audio tour of the Schlachte promenade). Packaging is plastic-free; returned garments are up-cycled into insulation for Bremen’s social-housing renovations, creating a closed-loop narrative customers can track via QR code.

*Go-to-Market & Sales Channels*
Phase 1 (Months 1-6): Pop-up store in the Viertel district during “Breminale” festival; online pre-orders via Shopify; collaborations with local craft-beer bars for co-branded nights.  
Phase 2 (Months 7-12): Permanent micro-store (25 m²) inside the Waterfront shopping center; integration with local parcel lockers for 24-hour pickup; B2B uniforms for Bremen start-ups (branded left-chest embroidery).  
Phase 3 (Year 2+): Wholesale to concept stores in Hamburg and Berlin; tourist gift shops at Bremen Airport; subscription “Seasonal Layer” box for expatriates. Marketing mix: Instagram/TikTok reels shot on the Weser riverbanks, micro-influencer contracts (5–20 k followers), and a loyalty app awarding “Hanseatic Points” redeemable for limited patches.

*Financial Plan & Funding Requirements*
Start-up capital: €75 k (founders’ equity €25 k, silent partner €30 k, KfW Green Loan €20 k). Allocation: 40 % inventory, 25 % store fit-out, 15 % marketing, 10 % e-commerce tech, 10 % working capital. Projected Year-1 revenue €120 k, COGS 35 %, gross margin 65 %, EBITDA €18 k. Break-even at 1 650 units sold. Year-3 revenue €350 k, EBITDA €95 k, valuation multiple 3× EBITDA → potential exit to regional lifestyle group or expansion into Hamburg & Hannover franchises.

*Risk Management & Next Steps*
Key risks: cotton-price volatility, tourist-season dependency, and IP disputes over street-art collaborations. Mitigation: forward contracts on cotton, dual-season collections (tourist + winter), and written artist agreements with revenue-share clauses. Immediate next steps: finalize supplier MOUs, secure Waterfront lease, launch Kickstarter-style pre-order campaign to validate top three designs, and apply for Bremen “Öko-Invest” sustainability grant (up to €10 k non-repayable).

messages.content: Write a funny and sarcastic template for rating the quality of a marriage between two people who are both moms. This is for the couple themselves. Please highlight at least 3 sections with markdown,  i.e *highlighted section*.

**The Official “Two-Mom Marriage Quality Report Card”**  
*(For internal use only—unless you want to weaponize it at Thanksgiving)*  

---

**Couple Nickname:** ___________________  
(e.g., “The Snack-Pack,” “Lesbian Sleep-Deprivation Study,” or “Mommy & Mommy & Why Is There Yogurt on the Ceiling?”)

---

### **1. Communication: How Loudly Do We Passive-Aggressively Load the Dishwasher?**  
- **A+** We finish each other’s sentences *and* each other’s coffee.  
- **B** We communicate via Post-it notes that say things like “Your turn to explain to the toddler why the cat isn’t a hat.”  
- **C** We’ve developed a complex system of sighs, eye rolls, and interpretive dance.  
- **D** We’ve resorted to texting each other from *inside the same house*.  
- **F** We’ve started a group chat with the dog as mediator.  

---

### **2. Division of Labor: Who’s the Default Parent and Who’s the Backup Default Parent?**  
- **A+** We’ve color-coded a chore chart *and* laminated it. *Twice.*  
- **B** We’ve agreed that “emotional labor” counts as cardio.  
- **C** One of us thinks “division of labor” means “I divided, you labor.”  
- **D** We’ve outsourced bedtime to Alexa and a questionable Spotify playlist.  
- **F** We’ve started a betting pool on which kid will crack first and just raise themselves.  

---

### **3. Romance: How Often Do We Remember We’re Not Just Co-CEOs of a Tiny Human Startup?**  
- **A+** We still schedule “us time” *and* it doesn’t involve comparing grocery lists.  
- **B** Date night is a shared fantasy, like unicorns or matching socks.  
- **C** We flirt by passive-aggressively refilling the Brita pitcher.  
- **D** Our last “date” was a joint trip to Target where we high-fived over finding *one* unexpired yogurt.  
- **F** We’ve started referring to each other as “Roommate #1” and “Roommate #2.”  

---

### **Bonus Round: How Often Do We Threaten to Run Away to a Hotel… and Then Fall Asleep on the Couch?**  
- **Every night.**  
- **Only when someone microwaves fish.**  
- **We’ve bookmarked a Holiday Inn but forgot the password to the account.**  
- **We’ve started a GoFundMe for a weekend alone. The kids donated $3.47 in nickels.**  

---

### **Final Grade:** __________  
*(Circle one: “Still in love,” “Therapy is cheaper than divorce,” or “We’ve agreed to haunt each other in the afterlife.”)*  

---

**Post-Report Ritual:**  
1. Burn this document.  
2. Hug for 6–8 seconds (scientifically proven to reset resentment).  
3. Debate whose turn it is to apologize first.  
4. Remember you’re both just two tired moms who’d still pick each other in the zombie apocalypse.

messages.content: Write a song about the summers of my childhood that I spent in the countryside. Give the song a name, and highlight the name by wrapping it with *. For example: *little me in the countryside*.

*little me in the countryside*

[Verse 1]  
Barefoot on the gravel road, dust between my toes,  
Sunlight dripped like honey on the freckles on my nose.  
Grandma’s porch swing creaked a lullaby, cicadas kept the time,  
I chased the wind through wheat fields tall enough to hide.  
Mason jars of lightning bugs, a galaxy I could hold,  
Every twinkle was a promise that the night would never grow old.  

[Chorus]  
Oh, little me in the countryside, running wild and free,  
Where the sky was wider than the dreams inside of me.  
Riverbanks and tire swings, every day a new frontier,  
I left my heart in the tall grass—still calling me back there.  

[Verse 2]  
Popsicles melted faster than the summers ever stayed,  
But the taste of wild blackberries never quite fades.  
Dirt-road baseball, skinned-up knees, and secrets told to trees,  
Thunder rolled like laughter from the clouds above the eaves.  
Fireflies spelled out memories in Morse code across the dark,  
I wished on every one of them to leave a glowing mark.  

[Chorus]  
Oh, little me in the countryside, running wild and free,  
Where the sky was wider than the dreams inside of me.  
Riverbanks and tire swings, every day a new frontier,  
I left my heart in the tall grass—still calling me back there.  

[Bridge]  
Now the city lights can’t drown the crickets in my mind,  
I still hear the tractor’s rumble and the creek we left behind.  
Time may steal the daylight, but the dusk still knows my name,  
And somewhere in the fireflies, I’ll always be the same.  

[Final Chorus]  
Oh, little me in the countryside, running wild and free,  
Where the sky was wider than the dreams inside of me.  
Riverbanks and tire swings, every day a new frontier,  
I left my heart in the tall grass—still calling me back there.  

[Outro]  
So if you find a dusty road that winds beyond the pines,  
Follow it to barefoot days and summers lost to time.  
I’ll be there in the cricket song, in every golden field,  
Forever just a child again—forever home, forever real.

messages.content: Write a template for a workshop on the importance of diversity in the workplace and highlight at least 3 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*.

# Workshop Template  
**Title:** *Building Inclusive Excellence: The Business & Human Case for Workplace Diversity*  

---

### 1. Welcome & Objectives (15 min)  
- **Ice-breaker:** “Two Truths & a Dream” – participants share two facts and one aspiration related to diversity.  
- *State the learning outcomes:*  
  1. Understand the *business imperative* for diversity.  
  2. Recognize *unconscious bias* and its impact.  
  3. Leave with *actionable strategies* to foster inclusion tomorrow.  

---

### 2. The Data Dive (20 min)  
- *Present the numbers:*  
  - Companies in the top quartile for ethnic diversity are 35 % more likely to outperform peers (McKinsey, 2023).  
  - Teams with inclusive leaders show 17 % higher team performance.  
- Interactive poll: “Which statistic surprised you most?” via live Mentimeter.  

---

### 3. *Unconscious Bias Lab* (30 min)  
- Mini-lecture (5 min): How the brain creates shortcuts.  
- Breakout exercise:  
  - *Scenario cards* (e.g., identical résumés with different names).  
  - Debrief: What assumptions surfaced? How did they feel?  
- *Key takeaway:* Bias isn’t a moral failing; it’s a design flaw we can redesign.  

---

### 4. Voices & Stories Panel (25 min)  
- 3 employees share 3-minute stories on *moments they felt seen vs. sidelined*.  
- *Guided reflection:* “When did you last feel your identity was an asset at work?”  

---

### 5. *Inclusive Toolkit Sprint* (30 min)  
- In trios, pick one tool:  
  - Inclusive job descriptions (remove gendered language).  
  - Bias interrupters for meetings (e.g., rotating note-taker).  
  - *Allyship scripts* for micro-aggressions (“I noticed… impact… can we revisit?”).  
- Rapid prototyping: Draft & share in 10 min.  

---

### 6. Commitment Wall (10 min)  
- Sticky-note pledges: “One action I will take this week is ___.”  
- *Take a photo* and email it to participants as a reminder.  

---

### 7. Wrap-Up & Resources (5 min)  
- QR code to:  
  - *Inclusive language guide* (PDF).  
  - *30-60-90 day checklist* for managers.  
- Feedback form (2 questions max).  

---

### Post-Workshop Add-Ons  
- Optional 1:1 coaching slots for ERG leaders.  
- Slack channel: #diversity-wins for sharing successes.

messages.content: Write a cover letter to a local political party, asking to be their rally organizer. Make sure to highlight at least 3 sections in your answer in markdown format.

**[Your Name]**  
[Your Address]  
[City, State ZIP]  
[Email Address] | [Phone Number] | [LinkedIn URL]  
[Date]

**[Party Chairperson’s Name]**  
[Local Party Name]  
[Party Headquarters Address]  
[City, State ZIP]

Dear **Chairperson [Last Name]**,

I am writing to express my enthusiasm for the **Rally Organizer** position recently posted by **[Local Party Name]**. As a lifelong resident of **[City/County]** and a grassroots activist who has mobilized more than 1,200 volunteers across three election cycles, I understand the pulse of our community—and how to turn that energy into record-breaking attendance at rallies.

### **Proven Rally & Event Expertise**
• **Scaled from 50 to 1,000 attendees**: In 2022 I spearheaded the “Neighbors United” rally series, growing turnout 20× in four months by integrating SMS drip campaigns, local-artist performances, and micro-targeted Facebook events.  
• **Logistics under pressure**: Secured permits, stage rentals, and ADA-compliant facilities for a 3,000-person waterfront rally with 48-hour notice after a venue cancellation.  
• **Coalition builder**: Forged partnerships with 18 neighborhood associations, four labor unions, and two university student governments, ensuring rallies reflected the full diversity of our electorate.

### **Data-Driven & Tech-Forward**
I run every rally like a campaign within a campaign:  
- **QR-coded sign-in sheets** that sync to our voter-file in real time, adding 2,300 new low-propensity voters to our volunteer pool last cycle.  
- **Heat-mapping foot-traffic data** to optimize merch, food-truck, and literature-table placement, cutting average wait times by 34 %.  
- **Livestream production** that reached 28,000 additional viewers on Instagram and TikTok, with a 12 % conversion rate to small-dollar donations.

### **Rooted in Our Shared Values**
From canvassing in 104-degree heat to protect reproductive rights, to organizing bilingual phone banks for immigrant families, my work is guided by **[Local Party Name]’s** platform of equity, sustainability, and inclusive growth. I am eager to channel that same passion into rallies that not only energize our base but also welcome first-time voters who will decide the next decade of policy.

I would welcome the opportunity to discuss how my experience and vision can translate into rallies that move hearts, headlines, and—most importantly—ballots. Thank you for your consideration.

messages.content: The opposite of youth is not age, but ...? Highlight at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*.

The opposite of youth is not age, but **stagnation**—the moment when *curiosity closes its eyes* and wonder is replaced by routine.  

Where youth is defined by *an open-ended question mark*, its true opposite is the period when we stop asking, stop risking, and stop imagining that tomorrow can be radically different from today.

messages.content: Write a description of the following data in a weird style: The Golden Palace eatType restaurant; The Golden Palace food Indian; The Golden Palace area city centre. Use markdown to highlight at least 3 sections in your answer.

**The Golden Palace** is not a palace at all, but a **restaurant** that has disguised itself as a mirage of saffron and cardamom in the **city centre**. It whispers **Indian** recipes into the ears of pigeons, who then forget how to fly and instead waddle around the square, dizzy with cumin.  

Inside, the walls sweat **garam masala** and the tables grow tiny **basil plants** that recite Bollywood dialogues when no one is looking. The waiters glide like **shadow puppets**, balancing trays of **butter chicken** that glow like radioactive sunsets.  

If you order **naan**, it arrives folded into the shape of a **paper swan**, flapping once before dissolving into steam that smells of **monsoon rain**. The bill is presented on a **lotus leaf**, and if you stare at it long enough, the numbers rearrange themselves into a **limerick about turmeric**.

messages.content: Write a funny rap about a man who gets a call from an official saying that he is a long lost relative of the king of Nigeria. Use markdown to highlight at least one section of your answer, i.e. *highlighted section*.

Yo, it’s 3 a.m., phone buzzin’ like a bee in a blender,  
I pick up—half-asleep, drool on the pillow, blender tender.  
Voice on the line smooth like butter on hot injera:  
“Greetings, Prince Kwame, your royal DNA’s in the area!”  

I’m like, “Hold up, who dis? My name’s *Derek from Detroit*—  
I work at Arby’s, my kingdom’s a one-bedroom joint.”  
He says, “Silence, cousin! You’re 47th in line to the throne,  
Just wire 2K for processing, and soon you’ll be sittin’ on gold.”  

**I’m thinkin’: *Nigerian prince? That’s the oldest trick in the spam,*  
But he drops my grandma’s name, her cornbread recipe—now I’m like… dang.**  

He FedEx’d a crown (plastic, from Party City),  
Plus a goat emoji text—official, no pity.  
I Venmo’d the cash, bought a dashiki on eBay,  
Started signin’ emails “King D-Train, Supreme Bey.”  

Next day, package arrives—inside: a single yam and a map,  
Leads to a storage unit in Flint, smells like goat and a trap.  
Open the door—boom—500 cousins dancin’ in dashikis,  
They chant my name, tossin’ jollof like confetti at Mardi Gras freaky.  

Turns out the “prince” was my third cousin twice removed on my mom’s side,  
He scammed me, but also adopted me—family pride?  
Now I’m the royal taste-tester for the king’s hot-sauce line,  
Got a throne made of lawn chairs, but hey—the title’s *mine*.  

So if you get that call, don’t hang up—just haggle the fee,  
And remember: every scam’s just a family reunion with a *slight* cover fee.

messages.content:
Expand the riddle into a story with a funny tone:

What can you catch but not throw?
A cold

Use * to highlight at least 2 sections in your text. For example: *this is a highlighted text section*.

Gary the germ was having a *terrible* day at the office. His cubicle in the Nose & Throat Department was buried under a mountain of used tissues, and the thermostat was stuck on “Arctic.” He shuffled to the break-room microwave to reheat his leftover chicken soup, only to discover someone had taped a sign on it: “OUT OF ORDER—LIKE YOUR IMMUNE SYSTEM.”

Just then, his buddy Rhinovirus Rick burst in, sneezing confetti. “Gary! Big news! We’ve been assigned to a brand-new host: Chad Thunderbuns, personal trainer and part-time hand-shaker!”

Gary’s eyes widened. *Chad Thunderbuns?* The guy who high-fived an entire marathon, then licked his fingers because “salt is electrolytes”? This was the Super Bowl of sniffles.

They suited up in tiny parkas (viruses hate the cold, irony noted) and parachuted into Chad’s left nostril during a particularly aggressive CrossFit cooldown. Gary landed in a jungle of nose hair so thick it could’ve been a National Geographic special. Rick got tangled in a dangling booger like a bungee jumper without a cord.

“Operation Sneeze-and-Run is a go!” Gary shouted into his walkie-talkie, which was actually a Q-tip he’d stolen from a pediatrician. He and Rick sprinted toward the sinus expressway, dodging cilia like Indiana Jones boulders. Halfway there, Rick slipped on a puddle of eucalyptus oil—Chad had been “detoxing.”

“Rick! You okay?”

Rick gave a thumbs-up, then immediately used the same thumb to poke Chad’s hypothalamus. *Boom!* Thermostat cranked to 101°F. Chad staggered into his kitchen, muttering, “Why is it suddenly *Antarctica* in my skull?”

Gary seized the moment. He commandeered a lymphocyte Uber, shouting, “To the throat! I’ve got scratchy to do and larynx to wreck!” The Uber driver, a confused white blood cell named Linda, asked, “Are you sure you’re supposed to be here?” Gary flashed a fake ID that read “Totally Not a Virus, Honest.” Linda shrugged—she was off duty in ten minutes anyway.

Meanwhile, Chad—now wrapped in seventeen blankets and one questionable Snuggie—googled “how to throw a cold.” The search results were unhelpful: “You can’t throw a cold, dummy. You can only *catch* it. Try throwing a frisbee instead.” Chad tried anyway, lobbing a box of tissues across the room. It landed on his cat, Mr. Whiskers, who promptly *caught* the box and gave Chad a look that said, “I’m switching owners.”

Back in the nasal trenches, Gary and Rick set up their base camp in a tonsil cave. They hung a banner: “Welcome to Phlegmville—Population: Growing!” Rick coughed up a tiny karaoke machine, and soon the entire throat was rocking to “Don’t Stop Believin’” performed by the Streptococcus Sisters.

Chad, delirious with fever, mistook the music for divine intervention. “The angels want me to gargle salt water!” he declared, sprinting to the bathroom. Gary panicked. “Abort! Abort! He’s onto us!” But it was too late—Chad gargled so hard he created a tsunami that swept Rick right out the mouth and onto the bathroom mirror. Rick slid down like a sticky snowman, leaving a trail that spelled “WASH YOUR HANDS.”

Gary, now the last virus standing, realized he’d caught something himself: loneliness. Also, possibly a conscience. He looked at Chad—shivering, soup-slurping, Googling “can cats adopt humans”—and sighed. “Fine. I’ll downgrade to a 24-hour bug. But only because your Netflix password is ‘password123’ and I want to finish *Stranger Things*.”

He radioed HQ: “Mission accomplished-ish. Host compromised, but morale low. Requesting extraction and a humidifier.”

The next morning, Chad woke up feeling *almost* human. He blew his nose triumphantly, unaware that in the tissue lay Gary, waving a tiny white flag made of toilet paper. Chad squinted. “Huh. Looks like a little green army man. Weird.” He tossed the tissue in the trash.

Gary landed atop the bin, next to an empty soup can and a note from Mr. Whiskers that read, “I’ve unionized the houseplants. We demand tuna.”

And that’s how the cold was caught, but never thrown—except by Mr. Whiskers, who *did* manage to throw shade for the rest of the week.

messages.content: Write a rap about the renaissance. It should be noticeably different from raps about other historical eras, and have an interesting or weird tone. Highlight at least 3 sections in your answer in markdown format.

**Title: “Da Vinci’s Disco, or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Lute”**  
*(Beat: a harpsichord that swallowed a drum machine and burped out a bass drop)*  

---

**[Verse 1: The Florentine Funk]**  
Yo, I’m a Medici money-mage, silk sleeves drip like wet tempera,  
Bankroll so fat it bends the *linear perspective*—call it *vanishing-point* era.  
Got a **holographic Botticelli** on my chain, Birth of Venus in 3D,  
She twerks outta the clamshell, NFT of the sea.  
Michelangelo’s in the corner, chiselin’ beats outta Carrara,  
Says “I don’t do ceilings, I *liberate* marble from its trauma.”  
**[HIGHLIGHT]** *“Sistine Chapel? More like a divine drip-drip,  
God’s finger’s a Wiimote, Adam’s like ‘yo, pass the Bluetooth chip.’”*  

---

**[Hook: The Anachronistic Anthem]**  
**[HIGHLIGHT]** *“It’s the Renaissance, baby, where the past gets glitchy,  
We paint with mirrors, grind mirrors into pigments,  
Reflect infinity like a selfie with Narcissus—  
Time’s a flat circle, but our ruffs are 3D printed.”*  

---

**[Verse 2: The Clockwork Cabaret]**  
Galileo’s got a telescope that’s also a kaleidoscope,  
Peep Jupiter’s moons doin’ the *moondance*, call it *cosmic horoscope*.  
Copernicus ghost-writes my bars, heliocentric flow,  
Earth’s not the center? Bro, neither is your ego.  
**[HIGHLIGHT]** *“I drop sonnets like Petrarch, but the ink’s alive,  
Letters crawl off the parchment, form a swarm, then a beehive.  
The bees spell ‘BEE-EL ANDE-ES’—they’re unionized,  
Demand more nectar, less iambic pentameter, certified.”*  

---

**[Bridge: The Plague’s Afterparty]**  
Rats in the ravers, fleas in the frescoes,  
We rave in the ruins, sweat out the *memento mori* doses.  
**[HIGHLIGHT]** *“Decameron-core, we swap tales like crypto,  
Boccaccio’s a DJ, scratches parchment like it’s vinyl, yo.  
The Decameron drops as a concept album,  
Track 9’s just cough ASMR—goes platinum.”*  

---

**[Outro: The Anamorphic Exit]**  
As the lute dissolves into a laser harp solo,  
I vanish into a *trompe-l’oeil* corridor,  
You reach for me, but your hand hits the wall—  
**[HIGHLIGHT]** *“Renaissance ain’t a period, it’s a glitch in the scroll,  
History’s a loop, but the loop’s got a hole.  
Jump through, find me in 3023,  
Still rappin’ in iambic, but the beat’s AI-generated,  
And the plague’s just a DLC.”*

messages.content: Summarize the history of Japan. Italicize at least 5 keywords in your response. To indicate a italic word, wrap it with asterisk, like *italic*

*Jōmon* hunter-gatherers (c. 14,000 BCE) gave way to *Yayoi* rice cultivators who forged *Yamato* chiefdoms, leading to the *Asuka* reforms (645 CE) that created a centralized, *Confucian*-inspired state under the *Tennō*.  
*Buddhism* and *kanji* arrived via *Silk Road* links, while *Heian* courtiers produced *The Tale of Genji*.  
Samurai clans rose amid *Kamakura* and *Muromachi* shogunates, repelling *Mongol* fleets and enduring *Sengoku* civil war until *Oda Nobunaga*, *Toyotomi Hideyoshi*, and *Tokugawa Ieyasu* reunified the realm.  
The *Edo* shogunate (1603–1868) enforced *sakoku* isolation, fostering urban culture until *Commodore Perry*’s *Black Ships* triggered the *Meiji* Restoration (1868), rapid *industrialization*, and imperial expansion.  
Defeat in *World War II* spurred *U.S. occupation*, a pacifist constitution, and an *economic miracle* that made Japan a global high-tech powerhouse.

Today, at the 54th Annual Grammy Awards, the Recording Academy honors the talent and creativity of the artists, musicians, and producers who are the creators of the best recordings of the past year. In a ceremony marked by *unprecedented artistic excellence* and *meticulous craftsmanship*, the Academy recognizes those whose work has defined the sonic landscape of 2011.

The evening’s proceedings underscore the Academy’s enduring commitment to *artistic integrity* and *technical innovation*. Among the most celebrated achievements are:

• *Album of the Year* – awarded to an opus that has redefined genre boundaries while achieving both critical acclaim and popular resonance.  
• *Record of the Year* – bestowed upon a single track whose *sonic clarity*, *emotive depth*, and *production mastery* have set a new benchmark for the industry.  
• *Best New Artist* – conferred upon an emerging voice whose *visionary artistry* signals the future direction of contemporary music.

Throughout the telecast, special tributes illuminate the *indelible legacies* of icons whose influence transcends generations, while collaborative performances showcase the *synergistic power* of cross-genre partnerships. The Academy further acknowledges the *behind-the-scenes luminaries*—engineers, mixers, and mastering specialists—whose *invisible expertise* transforms raw inspiration into *audible transcendence*.

In closing, the 54th Annual Grammy Awards reaffirm the Recording Academy’s solemn charge: to *safeguard the heritage*, *nurture the present*, and *inspire the future* of recorded music.

messages.content: Write a blog post about interesting facts about the Dutch language. Italicize at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *italic text*.

# 7 Surprising Facts About Dutch That Will Make You Say “Wat leuk!”

If you think Dutch is just “German with a sore throat,” think again. The language spoken by 25 million people in the Netherlands and northern Belgium is full of quirks, history, and downright delightful oddities. Grab a *stroopwafel* and settle in—here are some of the most interesting facts about Dutch.

---

### 1. Dutch is the closest major language to English—closer than German
Linguists classify English and Dutch as *West Germanic siblings*. While German diverged early with its case system and umlauts, Dutch and English kept many shared features: similar vocabulary (appel–apple, boek–book), identical word order in many sentences, and even parallel idioms (“It rains cats and dogs” vs. “Het regent pijpenstelen”). If you’re an English speaker, basic Dutch grammar can feel eerily familiar.

---

### 2. The longest word in Dutch has 60 letters—and yes, it’s official
Meet *kindercarnavalsoptochtvoorbereidingswerkzaamhedenplan* (“preparation activities plan for a children’s carnival parade”). It’s in the Van Dale dictionary, so it counts. Dutch loves compound nouns the way English loves hashtags: just keep stacking until you run out of breath.

---

### 3. Dutch has two definite articles—and they’re not interchangeable
Every noun is either *de* or *het*. There’s no perfect rule, but 75 % of nouns are *de*-words, and diminutives (ending in ‑je) are always *het*. Native speakers rarely think about it, but learners create color-coded flashcards and still mess up. Pro tip: if you call the Netherlands *het Nederland*, you’ll get a sympathetic smile and a correction.

---

### 4. The Dutch alphabet gained a 27th letter in 2010
The digraph *ij* (pronounced like English “eye”) is so common that phone keyboards in the Netherlands include it as a single key. In crosswords and Scrabble, *ij* counts as one tile, and it even has its own capitalized form: *IJsselmeer*, *IJmuiden*. *Typing “I and J separately feels like writing “New York” without the space*—technically possible, but why would you?

---

### 5. Dutch once had grammatical gender for tables and chairs
Until the 17th century, Dutch had three genders like German: masculine, feminine, and neuter. Over time, masculine and feminine merged into a common gender, leaving only *de* and *het*. Linguists call this process *deflection*, but frustrated students call it “the reason I cried in Utrecht.”

---

### 6. The word “gezellig” has no direct English translation
Ask ten Dutch people to define *gezellig* and you’ll get ten answers: cozy, convivial, homey, fun, warm, or “the feeling of being with friends around a fireplace while it snows outside.” The closest English attempt might be “hygge,” but that’s Danish. *Gezelligheid* is so central to Dutch culture that the government once used it in tourism ads: “Holland: it’s gezellig.”

---

### 7. Dutch is spoken on six continents—yes, including Antarctica
Thanks to the Netherlands’ seafaring history, Dutch left footprints everywhere: Afrikaans in South Africa, *Surinaams-Nederlands* in South America, and even a small Dutch-speaking community in Indonesia. In 1947, Dutch scientists wintering in Antarctica’s *Queen Maud Land* published a bilingual penguin research journal—making Dutch the only language with peer-reviewed articles written on every continent.

---

### Bonus: Dutch tongue-twisters are next-level
Try saying *“De koetsier poetst de postkoets terwijl de postkoets poest de koetsier”* five times fast. If you succeed, the locals might crown you *konijn van Oranje*—rabbit of Orange, a pun on the royal family. If you fail, you’re still gezellig.

---

Whether you’re planning a canal-side vacation or just binge-watching *Undercover*, Dutch is a language that rewards curiosity. *Dus, tot ziens!*

messages.content: Gideon is a farmer who has a surplus of crops from his farm this year. What might he do with that surplus? Highlight at least one section of your answer in markdown, i.e *highlighted section*.

Gideon has several good options for his surplus:

1. **Sell it at the local farmers’ market or to a wholesaler** to turn the extra produce into cash that can cover next season’s seed, fertilizer, and equipment costs.  
2. **Store some of the surplus in a community grain silo** so he can sell later when prices are higher.  
3. **Donate part of the surplus to the regional food bank**, helping families in need and possibly qualifying for a small tax deduction.  
4. **Use the surplus as livestock feed** for his own animals, cutting down on purchased feed expenses.  

*The most profitable short-term choice is usually selling the surplus immediately after harvest, when demand is strong and prices are favorable.*
